content.title: EXPLORING RENEWABLE TECHNOLOGIES FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION
content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

In this lesson, we will explore five key renewable energy technologies that are playing a pivotal role in climate mitigation and shaping the global energy transition. While there are numerous emerging and nascent technologies on the horizon, the focus here will be on those that are already having a significant impact or show strong potential to drive the transition to a low-carbon future. Understanding these technologies is crucial for advancing sustainable energy solutions and achieving the goals of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and limiting global warming.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: bioenergy
concepts.body: Bioenergy is energy derived from organic materials, such as plants and animal waste, which can be converted into fuels or electricity.

concepts.title: energy storage
concepts.body: Energy storage refers to the capture and holding of energy for use at a later time, allowing for the balancing of supply and demand in energy systems.

concepts.title: hydrogen for development
concepts.body: Hydrogen for development refers to the use of hydrogen as a clean energy source to support economic growth, enhance energy security, and promote sustainable development, particularly in developing countries.

content.text: CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION

Climate change mitigation refers to any action taken by governments, businesses or people to reduce or prevent greenhouse gases, or to enhance carbon sinks that remove them from the atmosphere. Mitigation efforts include transitioning to renewable energy sources, enhancing energy efficiency, adopting regenerative agricultural practices and protecting and restoring forests and critical ecosystems. Effective mitigation requires a whole-of-society approach and structural transformations to reduce emissions and limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels.

By the end of 2024, global renewable energy capacity had reached approximately 4,448 GW. Solar power remained the dominant source, contributing 1,865 GW to the total. Hydropower and wind energy also played significant roles, with installed capacities of 1,283 GW and 1,133 GW, respectively. Other renewable sources included 151 GW from bioenergy, 15 GW from geothermal energy, and 0.5 GW from marine energy. Following these updated figures, we will take a closer look at five key renewable technologies, examining their advancements, applications, and role in the global energy transition.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Solar Energy

content.text: Solar power is one of the cleanest and most abundant renewable energy sources available. It can be harnessed through various technologies, such as solar photovoltaics (PV), concentrated solar power (CSP), and solar thermal systems. Solar PV technology is the most widespread, transforming sunlight into electricity via silicon semiconductors. However, PV systems require battery storage to retain electricity for nighttime use. In 2023, solar PV accounted for three-quarters of all renewable power capacity additions, with global capacity reaching a record 473 gigawatts. CSP, on the other hand, uses mirrors to concentrate sunlight, generating heat for power production, and it can store energy for use at night. In 2020, CSP’s installed capacity reached 7 gigawatts, showing significant growth since 2010.

Solar power plays a critical role in reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. For example, solar PV produces about 43-45 grams of CO2 per kWh through its lifecycle as discussed in the previous chapter. When replacing fossil fuel power with solar PV, an acre of solar panels can save up to 198 metric tons of CO2 annually. Additionally, the cost of solar panels has dramatically dropped, with prices falling 93% from 2010 to 2020, making solar power the most affordable energy source in many regions.

The solar energy market has driven job creation as well. In 2023, approximately 7.1 million people were employed in solar PV, with China, dominating the workforce with 4.6 million jobs. Employment in clean energy continued to surpass fossil fuel jobs, reaching 34.8 million positions compared to 32.6 million in the fossil fuel sector.
Challenges to Solar Power Implementation

While solar power has immense potential, there are challenges to widespread implementation: Grid Integration: Solar energy is variable and dependent on weather and location. Managing this variability requires investments in grid infrastructure, storage, and demand response. Cost in Low-Income Countries: Solar projects face higher capital costs in developing countries due to factors such as governance issues and currency fluctuations. Access to Funding: Solar transitions in low-income countries are often hindered by limited access to finance. Wealthier countries, though more capable of investing, still face issues with equitable distribution of technologies and grid integration

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 12
content.title: Part 2: Wind Energy

content.text: Wind power harnesses the kinetic energy of the wind through turbines that convert it into electrical energy, producing minimal greenhouse gas emissions compared to other energy sources. Over the past decade, wind technology has seen significant innovations, improving efficiency, power, and capacity while reducing noise. Wind installations now include onshore, offshore, and floating platforms capable of withstanding extreme conditions, such as hurricane-force winds. Offshore wind, with its stronger and more consistent winds, is expected to grow as siting challenges are addressed. Wind power currently accounts for 6-7% of global electricity, with substantial potential to meet global energy needs. Wind energy is a crucial component of global climate strategies, particularly under the IEA Net Zero Emissions (NZE) Scenario, as emphasized in the UAE Consensus, which calls for doubling energy efficiency and tripling renewable energy capacity by 2030. In 2022, wind power grew by 17%, contributing to a combined 12% share of global electricity generation alongside solar PV. Wind energy's near-zero greenhouse gas emissions and high energy return on energy invested (EROEI) make it an essential solution for reducing emissions. Additionally, wind power supports job creation, particularly in China and Europe, with 1.4 million jobs in 2022. Wind turbines have an operational lifespan of 20 years, running nearly emissions-free after offsetting construction emissions within 3-6 months.
Challenges to Wind Power Implementation

Volatile Markets: Supply chain issues, rising demand, and cost increases (raw materials, shipping, interest rates, and inflation) have delayed or shelved some wind projects. This is also in several cases accompanied by weak political will. Cost for Lower-Income Countries: Access to capital and higher project financing costs in developing countries pose challenges for wind energy deployment, particularly for onshore wind projects. High Initial Costs: Setting up a wind farm involves significant upfront investment in turbines and associated infrastructure. Grid Integration: Integrating variable wind power into the existing electricity grid requires sophisticated management systems to maintain grid stability.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 2 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Kazakhstan

content.text: Case Study RBEC: Kazakhstan —Wind Power Market Development Initiative

The Wind Power Market Development Initiative, launched in 2004 by UNDP and GEF in collaboration with the Government of Kazakhstan, sought to establish a sustainable wind energy sector in Kazakhstan. This ambitious project aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions while tapping into the country's substantial wind energy potential, estimated at 929 billion kWh annually, equivalent to 154 GW of installed capacity. By the time the project concluded in 2011, it had laid critical groundwork for wind energy development, addressing systemic barriers and fostering a more favorable environment for renewable energy investment. At the outset, the project faced significant obstacles. Awareness of wind energy’s potential was minimal, and technical capacity within the country was underdeveloped. There were no operational wind farms to provide a proof of concept, and financial barriers loomed large, including low electricity tariffs, high commercial risks, and challenges in securing both domestic and foreign investment. Institutional barriers further hindered progress, with an absence of dedicated policies, regulatory frameworks, and centralized mechanisms to promote and manage wind energy projects.

Despite these challenges, the initiative achieved transformative outcomes. It facilitated the creation of the National Wind Power Development Program, which set ambitious targets for wind energy generation, aiming for 750 million kWh by 2015 and 5 billion kWh by 2030. A wind atlas was developed and made publicly accessible, providing valuable data to investors and developers. Comprehensive studies on technical, environmental, and commercial aspects were conducted, including assessments of grid capacity and innovative financing mechanisms. These efforts ensured that no insurmountable obstacles stood in the way of wind energy development in Kazakhstan.

The project’s legacy includes a shift in government policies, culminating in the acknowledgment of the need for fixed feed-in tariffs to replace ad hoc, project-specific agreements. This policy change has the potential to reduce risks for developers and attract sustained investment in the sector. While feed-in tariffs were once a key tool for investment certainty, many markets are now shifting toward auction-based systems or moving away from subsidies altogether as renewable energy becomes increasingly cost-competitive. The initiative also fostered capacity-building through training programs, enabling local professionals to acquire expertise in wind energy technologies, resource assessment, and project planning. Over 100 professionals were trained, and specialized software tools were introduced to streamline project development processes. Significant progress was also made in engaging stakeholders, from government agencies to private investors. The establishment of partnerships with international and national organizations laid the foundation for ongoing collaboration and knowledge sharing. The project’s achievements underscore the importance of aligning technical expertise, regulatory frameworks, and financial incentives to foster renewable energy growth.

While much has been accomplished, challenges remain. Ensuring policy stability, enhancing grid infrastructure, and further refining financial mechanisms are critical for scaling up wind energy. Continued cooperation among government entities, international partners, and private sector stakeholders will be essential to build on the project’s success and fully realize Kazakhstan’s vast wind energy potential. This case study highlights the transformative impact of targeted interventions in overcoming barriers to renewable energy development. By addressing systemic challenges and creating an enabling environment, the initiative has not only advanced Kazakhstan’s wind energy sector but also provided a valuable model for similar efforts in other emerging markets.
References

Global Environment Facility. 2011. “Lessons Learnt from the UNDP-GEF Project ‘Kazakhstan — Wind Power Market Development Initiative.’” The United Nations Development Programme. Kazakhstan: UNDP Kazakhstan.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Hydropower

content.text: Hydropower is a significant renewable energy source that harnesses the potential energy of water flowing from higher to lower elevations. It can be categorized into different types, including storage dams and “run-of-river” systems. Large storage dams provide backup power and rapid response during outages, while run-of-river plants offer continuous base load energy. Hydropower is highly valuable for grid stability, providing fast-response generation and supporting frequency stability. However, its potential is influenced by climate-related changes in rainfall and ecosystems, with droughts posing a challenge. Hydropower offers substantial carbon emissions reductions, saving up to 4 billion tonnes of CO2 annually compared to coal. It accounts for about 9% of global CO2 emissions reduction. In the IEA Net Zero Emissions by 2050 scenario, hydropower continues to grow at an average rate of 4% annually. There remains considerable untapped potential for hydropower development. Global technical potential is estimated at 14,576 TWh/year, over four times current generation levels. Africa, in particular, holds vast undeveloped potential, offering significant opportunities for growth.
Challenges to Hydro Power Implementation

High Initial Investment: Both large-scale hydropower projects and hydro mini-grids require significant upfront capital. This is often a barrier in developing countries with limited financial resources. Infrastructure Limitations: Developing countries often lack the necessary infrastructure to support large-scale hydropower projects. This includes not only the physical infrastructure for dams but also transmission lines to distribute electricity. Ecological and Social Impact: Hydropower projects can disrupt ecosystems, alter water flow, and negatively affect biodiversity. Large dams may also lead to community displacement, triggering social unrest. Geopolitical Tensions: Hydropower development can exacerbate transboundary water disputes, especially in regions where multiple countries rely on shared water resources.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 4
content.title: Part 4: Geothermal

content.text: Geothermal energy provides reliable, base-load power and heating/cooling from a widely available resource. It offers sustainable production and generates cost-effective, dispatchable power, unaffected by climate conditions. Geothermal energy has lower greenhouse gas emissions compared to traditional base-load thermal generation. In off-peak periods, it can also help recharge battery-powered vehicles, further reducing CO2 emissions. Geothermal energy can become a key part of future electricity and heating systems, offering a clean and reliable energy source. Right now, geothermal meets less than 1% of global energy demand, and its use is mostly in countries with easily accessible, high-quality resources like the United States, Iceland, Indonesia, Türkiye, Kenya, and Italy.

Geothermal energy has the potential to significantly contribute to global electricity demand by 2050. Advancements in technology and reductions in project costs could enable the deployment of up to 800 gigawatts (GW) of geothermal capacity worldwide, generating nearly 6,000 terawatt-hours annually—equivalent to the current combined electricity consumption of the United States and India. A notable advantage of geothermal power is its ability to provide continuous, baseload electricity. Geothermal plants can operate at full capacity 24/7, offering a reliable energy source. In 2023, global geothermal capacity had a utilization rate exceeding 75%, significantly higher than wind power's less than 30% and solar photovoltaic's (PV) less than 15%. Additionally, geothermal plants can operate flexibly, aiding in grid stabilization and complementing intermittent renewable sources like solar PV and wind. The International Energy Agency (IEA) projects that, with appropriate support, costs for next-generation geothermal technologies could decrease by 80% by 2035. At this cost level, geothermal plants could produce electricity at approximately $50 per megawatt-hour (MWh), positioning them among the most affordable dispatchable low-emission electricity sources, comparable to or cheaper than hydro, nuclear, and bioenergy. Furthermore, geothermal energy would be highly competitive with solar and wind power when paired with battery storage.
Challenges to Geothermal Energy Implementation

Global Coordination and Classifications: The lack of standardized guidelines for geothermal resource assessment, efficiency, and environmental impact hampers transparency and comparability. This hinders progress and accurate assessments of how geothermal energy is operating and performing. This leads to ambiguity in reporting and a limited understanding of what needs to be done differently. Cost and technology: High-grade geothermal resources have restricted geographic distribution. There are cost and technological hurdles to using low-grade geothermal resources and EGS. The levelized cost of geothermal energy has increased 36% from 2010-2021, more than any other energy source examined in that research. High-quality geothermal resources are already economically competitive with market energy costs in many areas. Public and private research funding and favorable deployment rules may be required to develop and commercialize lower-grade hydrothermal deposits. The effectiveness of these efforts may play an important role in determining the magnitude of geothermal energy's contributions to long-term GHG emissions reductions.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 5
content.title: Part 5: Hydrogen

content.text: Hydrogen is a versatile energy carrier, with clean hydrogen produced from renewables helping sectors like long-haul transport, chemicals, and iron and steel. Blue hydrogen, made from natural gas through methods like steam methane reforming and autothermal reforming, produces CO2 but can capture and store it. Green hydrogen, produced through electrolysis using renewable electricity, has no harmful by-products. Hydrogen plays a fundamental role in mitigating sectors that have proven hard to abate. Global hydrogen demand grew by 3% in 2022 to 95 million tonnes. There are mainly heavy industry, shipping, long-distance land transport, and aviation. Implementing clean hydrogen provides relatively low technical challenges in the refining and fertilizer sectors, as it can be a like-for-like substitution for others. More than 393 agreements were made related to hydrogen in 2022.

While this marks significant progress for a growing sector, most production is still in the planning or early stages. To fully realize the project pipeline, the sector must grow at an extraordinary rate of over 90% annually from 2024 to 2030, far surpassing the growth of solar PV during its peak expansion.
Government Policies and Regulatory Frameworks

Incentives and Subsidies: Governments can enhance the attractiveness of renewable investments by offering financial incentives such as subsidies, tax breaks, and feed-in tariffs that guarantee fixed prices for renewable energy. Clear Regulatory Frameworks: Establishing transparent and supportive regulations can simplify the approval processes for renewable projects, reducing bureaucratic delays and building investor confidence.
Challenges to Geothermal Energy Implementation

High Costs: Hydrogen production is expensive, often 2-3 times more costly than fossil fuel alternatives. Pipelines, fuel cells, and storage tanks also carry high costs. Lack of Standards: The absence of globally accepted standards for measuring and certifying the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions of hydrogen production creates inconsistencies across markets, complicating efforts to compare its environmental impact. Traditional classifications based on color labels (e.g., green, blue, gray hydrogen) lack precision and fail to account for varying emissions intensities. Cross-Border Cooperation: Transporting and storing hydrogen requires significant infrastructure investment and international collaboration, as imported hydrogen is often cheaper than local production.
Innovative Financing Mechanisms

Blended Finance and De-risking Mechanisms: Mobilizing private capital is essential to bridge the energy finance gap. Expanding financial structures such as blended finance, alongside financial de-risking mechanisms like guarantee schemes will for sure encourage private sector participation. International Financial Support: Actively seeking partnerships with international financial institutions to access grants and concessional loans aimed at renewable energy projects is important.

Water Consumption: The production of hydrogen, particularly through electrolysis, requires significant water resources. In areas where water scarcity is an issue, this could pose a serious environmental concern. Safety Concerns: Hydrogen storage and transport require high-pressure systems, raising concerns about potential leaks, explosions, and safety risks to nearby communities. Unequal distribution of benefits: Like with any technology, concerns exist about ensuring equitable access to hydrogen technology and its benefits across different socioeconomic groups and regions.
Infrastructure Development

Grid Modernization: Upgrading existing grid infrastructure is essential for accommodating the variable nature of renewables. Investments in smart grid technologies can improve reliability and efficiency in energy distribution. Energy Storage Solutions: Implementing energy storage systems is crucial for managing the intermittency of renewable sources, allowing excess energy to be stored for use during low generation periods.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 6
content.title: Part 6: Strategies to Overcome Challenges in Renewable Technology Implementation in Developing Countries

content.text: Capacity Building and Technical Expertise

Training Programs: Developing a skilled workforce through targeted training initiatives can help address the technical expertise gap necessary for deploying and maintaining renewable technologies effectively. Public-Private Partnerships: Collaborations between governments, private sector entities, and non-profit organizations can facilitate knowledge transfer and resource sharing, enhancing local capabilities in renewable technology implementation.
Community Engagement and Awareness

Local Involvement: Engaging communities in the planning and execution of renewable projects ensures that solutions are tailored to local needs, enhancing acceptance and sustainability. Awareness Campaigns: Educating communities about the benefits and the associated risks of renewable energy can drive demand and support for clean energy initiatives, overcoming resistance based on a lack of information.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

objectives.title: Diverse Renewable Technologies are Key to Emission Reductions.
objectives.description: Solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, and hydrogen are playing a crucial role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and accelerating the global energy transition. Each technology has unique advantages, such as solar PV’s affordability, wind energy’s scalability, hydropower’s grid stability, geothermal’s reliability, and hydrogen’s potential for hard-to-abate sectors.

objectives.title: Implementation Challenges Must Be Addressed.
objectives.description: While renewable energy technologies offer significant benefits, their implementation faces challenges, including high initial investment costs, grid integration issues, financing constraints, and infrastructure limitations, particularly in developing countries.

objectives.title: Strategic Approaches are Essential for Scaling Renewable Energy.
objectives.description: Policy incentives, innovative financing (e.g., blended finance and concessional loans), infrastructure development (grid modernization and energy storage), capacity building, and community engagement are key strategies for scaling up renewable energy deployment, ensuring equitable access, and supporting a just energy transition.
